channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Amid Coups and Covid, Africa Focuses on What’s Most Important: Soccer
item.description: Many countries competing in the Africa Cup of Nations are enduring security, economic and political crises, but the tournament offers visions of unity, solidarity and joy.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Brenda Kiven and Tom Saater
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Senegalese fans in Yaoundé, Cameroon, on Wednesday. The Africa Cup of Nations tournament has brought some respite for countries going through major political upheavals, war and the pandemic.

item.title: Leader’s Death Is Another Blow for ISIS, but It’s Hardly the End
item.description: The Islamic State is a shadow of its former self. But it’s likely to keep adapting and enduring, even after the U.S. raid that killed its top commander.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: American and Kurdish forces confronted ISIS fighters recently in Syria, in some of the heaviest fighting by U.S. troops in the region in three years.

item.title: Facing Tough Election, Orban Turns to Putin for Support
item.description: The Hungarian leader made his name by defying Moscow. But he has increasingly turned toward Russia in an effort to secure the natural gas he needs to keep energy prices low and voters happy.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Novak and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, long seen as a political chameleon, has broken with his country’s long history of wariness toward Russia.

item.title: Live Updates: Tense Wait as Rescuers Work to Free 5-Year-Old From Well in Morocco
item.description: A boy named Rayan has been stuck at the bottom of a 100-foot-deep well since Tuesday, in a drama that has captivated the North African nation.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescuers working on Friday to save a 5-year-old child who fell down a well in northern Morocco.

item.title: Collateral Damage of China's Virus Policy: Fruit
item.description: The closure of Chinese land borders and the tightened screening of goods have driven Southeast Asian fruit farmers into debt. Many have had to abandon their harvest.
item.dc:creator: Vo Kieu Bao Uyen, Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pham Thanh Hong, a dragon fruit farmer in Vietnam, trimming his trees, which were adorned with LED lights to induce off-season flowering.

item.title: Fahad Shah, Editor in Kashmir, Is Arrested
item.description: The police accused Fahad Shah, who edits a news website, of “uploading anti-national content.” Critics say journalists in Kashmir have increasingly been harassed and intimidated.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Fahad Shah, right, editor of The Kashmir Walla, last month. His arrest showed the Kashmir authorities’ “utter disregard for press freedom,” the Committee to Protect Journalists said.

item.title: In Beijing, Olympic Spectacle and Global Power Games
item.description: The opening of the Winter Games gave Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin a chance to cement their partnership against Western censure.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at the Winter Olympics opening ceremony on Friday in Beijing.

item.title: Russian Troops in Final Stages of Readiness Add to Worries for Ukraine
item.description: Though the Kremlin’s intentions are unclear, Ukrainian officials are newly worried about the Crimean Peninsula, where Russia has deployed 10,000 additional troops, they said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: A satellite image released this month by Maxar shows Russian battle groups and tents in Bakhchysarai, Crimea.

item.title: Five Takeaways From the U.S. Raid That Killed the Islamic State’s Leader
item.description: A daring raid by U.S. Special Operations forces that resulted in the death of the ISIS leader offered a vivid reminder that the chaos in Syria continues to reverberate.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali and Marc Santora
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The house in Atmeh, Syria, in which Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi, the leader of the Islamic State, was living.

item.title: How Randa Abd Al-Aziz, a Black Iraqi, Got a Sudden Career in TV News
item.description: Randa Abd Al-Aziz was joking with friends in a Baghdad cafe when she got a surprise job offer: broadcasting the news in Iraq, whose Black citizens have little media presence and even less power.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Aline Deschamps for The New York Times
item.media:description: Randa Abd Al-Aziz is the only Black Iraqi who has been employed on air at the state television’s news and information channels in the last 20 years — and possibly ever.

item.title: On Ukraine, Many Russians Have No Doubt: It’s the Fault of the U.S.
item.description: The idea that the U.S. and NATO are fomenting the crisis between Russia and Ukraine is hammered home daily by the Kremlin’s propaganda machine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Moscow this week, where many Russians blamed the United States for the Ukraine crisis while others preferred not to think about it.

item.title: Lone ISIS Bomber Carried Out Kabul Airport Attack, U.S. Says
item.description: The suicide bombing killed as many as 170 civilians and 13 U.S. troops in the final days of U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victims of a suicide bombing at the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, arrived at a hospital in August.

item.title: Apathy and Anger in France’s Election Everytown
item.description: Auxerre has backed the winner in every French presidential race for 40 years. This time, the town’s politics are drifting right, and many struggling residents see little to vote for.
item.dc:creator: Léontine Gallois
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Auxerre has consistently voted for the winning presidential candidate for the past 40 years.

item.title: New Zealand Inquiry Finds Hundreds of Reports of Abuse by Priests
item.description: The complaints, going back seven decades, attest to the pervasiveness of sexual and other abuse within the Catholic Church and are part of a worldwide reckoning.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests
item.media:description: A Mass in Auckland, New Zealand, in 2014.

item.title: Ottawa Residents Fed Up With Trucker Convoy Protests
item.description: Although the focus has been on protests in front of Parliament, three Ottawa neighborhoods have also been upturned by the demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters on Parliament Hill a week ago.

item.title: ‘Guernica’ Antiwar Tapestry to Be Rehung at U.N.
item.description: The canvas replica of Picasso’s painting, symbolizing war’s horrors, had been a photogenic fixture at the United Nations for decades before its owner, the Rockefeller family, removed it last year.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: The floor-to-ceiling reproduction of Pablo Picasso’s “Guernica” was a fixture outside the United Nations Security Council before it was removed in February of last year.

item.title: Southwest Airlines to Start Selling Alcohol on Flights Again
item.description: A flight attendants’ union said the decision was “unsafe and irresponsible.”
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Southwest Airlines plans to resume serving alcohol on flights in two weeks. The union representing flight attendants is worried that passengers who drink may become unruly in the skies.

item.title: Younger Americans Benefited Less From Booster Shots Than Older People
item.description: Among those under age 50, vaccination even without a booster protected strongly against hospitalization and death, according to new C.D.C. data.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Administering a booster in the Bronx last month. The data suggest that boosters are most essential for older adults and those who have certain immune conditions or live in long-term care facilities.

item.title: Rescuers in Morocco Race to Save 5-Year-Old Stuck in Well for Days
item.description: People in the region were glued to the rescue effort on television and online, eager for some good news at a time when many have been buffeted by Covid pandemic gloom.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Dan Bilefsky and Aida Alami
item.media:description: Rescuers were at work on Thursday in Tomrote, in northern Morocco, where a 5-year-old boy fell to the bottom of a 100-foot-deep well.

item.title: They Survived Guns and Machetes in Congo. They Want the World to Know.
item.description: After a brazen assault on a displaced persons camp that killed about 60 people, the most seriously wounded were airlifted to a hospital where a Times photographer recorded their accounts.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Logo Lupka, 65, had fled his village only a week before the attack on the camp. He was shot in the hip, but his wife was shot and killed in the tent beside him. “Only God can help me now,” he said.

item.title: The C.D.C. Adds Wastewater Data to Its Covid-19 Tracker
item.description: Analyzing wastewater can help officials estimate how prevalent the virus is in a community and which variants are circulating.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A wastewater treatment plant and overflow facility in Farmington, W.Va., in October.

item.title: Ukraine Shows Off New U.S. Weaponry, in a Signal to Russia
item.description: As the United States and others step up military aid to Ukraine, the deliveries are more overt, and Ukraine is staging public weapons demonstrations for the media.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier demonstrates an American-provided M141 “bunker-buster” missile in Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: India's Latest Covid Surge May Be Declining, Officials Say
item.description: “We are seeing the pandemic situation has improved,” said Dr. V.K. Paul, the head of India’s Covid task force.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: Testing for the coronavirus in Jammu, India, last month.

item.title: Pandemic-era tests could help efforts to eliminate hepatitis C.
item.dc:creator: Ted Alcorn
item.media:credit: Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times
item.media:description: For many patients, navigating a complex pathway to treatment for hepatitis C can be “a big barrier,“ said Dr. Lucinda Grande.

item.title: Captain James Cook’s Ship Caught in Center of a Maritime Rift
item.description: After researchers in Australia reported finding the wreck of the Endeavour off Rhode Island, their U.S. partners issued a startling rebuke.
item.dc:creator: Manan Luthra
item.media:description: A replica of James Cook’s HMB Endeavour in Sydney. Experts say they may have found the shipwreck in Newport Harbor, R.I.

item.title: Zero Covid in China
item.description: China’s zero-Covid policy has kept deaths very low. Can it continue?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A train station in Beijing where express trains connect Olympic venues.

item.title: Talking Points With … Who Else? The Points Guy
item.description: Brian Kelly has been helping travelers and other consumers navigate the increasingly complicated loyalty universe for over a decade. Here’s what he has to say about playing the points game.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: Why I’ve Learned to Loathe Australia’s Trivial Politics
item.description: This week has shown just how ill-equipped the current Australian political ecosystem is when facing catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: ISIS leader dead in U.S. raid.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The aftermath of an operation by U.S. forces early Thursday in Atmeh, Syria.

item.title: Raid Targeting ISIS Leader Came After Months of Planning
item.description: President Biden said the attack on Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi was designed to minimize civilian casualties, but then the terrorist leader set off a bomb.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Neighbors Recall Night of Fear in Syria Raid That Killed ISIS Leader
item.description: In a village in Syria, residents took cover, watched and hid as U.S. forces assaulted the house next door, killing the leader of ISIS.
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Haj Kadour and Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The house in Atmeh, Syria, where the leader of ISIS, Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi, lived on the third floor, until Thursday.

item.title: Top Aides to Boris Johnson Quit, Adding to Downing Street Turmoil
item.description: Day after day, new developments add to the political crisis over boozy parties during lockdown, which threatens to bring down the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain departing No. 10 Downing Street to answer questions in Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden Calls Death of ISIS Leader a Warning
item.description: At least 13 people were killed during the pre-dawn raid.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: The aftermath of a U.S. raid in which the leader of the Islamic State, Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi, was killed in Idlib, Syria, on Thursday.

item.title: A Deluge of Medical Waste Is Swamping the Globe, a U.N. Report Says.
item.description: Discarded syringes, old test kits and used vaccine vials have strained waste management systems and are threatening people’s health and the environment.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: A dump with disposed medical waste bags outside a hospital in New Delhi in 2020.

item.title: Turkey, a Sometimes Wavering NATO Ally, Backs Ukraine
item.description: In a public rebuke of Russia, Turkey will expand supplies of one of the Ukrainian Army’s most sophisticated weapons, a long-range, Turkish-made armed drone.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops crossed a river Thursday to take up a position on the frontline in Schastia, Ukraine. Turkey said Thursday that it would provide weapons to Ukraine.

item.title: Austria Will Soon Require Most Adults to Get a Covid Vaccine
item.description: The measure requires almost everyone 18 or over to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, a wider-ranging mandate than any other European country has yet imposed.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: A woman receiving a Covid vaccine shot in Salzburg, Austria, last month.

item.title: Food Prices Approach Record Highs, Threatening the World’s Poorest
item.description: The prices have climbed to their highest level since 2011, according to a U.N. index. It could cause social unrest “on a widespread scale,” one expert said.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Corn harvest in Knox County, Neb., in October. Farmers around the world face numerous challenges in bringing their products to market.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Planned to Fabricate Pretext for Invasion
item.description: Officials said Russia was planning a fake video showing an attack by Ukrainians on Russian territory or Russian speakers in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers — real ones — near the front line on Thursday.

item.title: Rotterdam May Dismantle Part of Bridge for Jeff Bezos’ Superyacht
item.description: The Dutch city of Rotterdam walked back earlier comments that the historic Koningshaven Bridge would be briefly dismantled. On Thursday, officials said a decision had not yet been made.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Officials in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, received a request to dismantle part of the Koningshaven “De Hef” lift bridge to let Jeff Bezos’ new luxury yacht pass.

item.title: Who Was ISIS Leader Abu Ibrahim al-Hashemi al-Qurayshi?
item.description: Little is known about the ISIS leader, who died, much like his predecessor, in a raid by U.S. commandos in northwestern Syria.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A photo supplied by the U.S. government showing Mr. al-Qurayshi, who was named the head of ISIS in 2019.

item.title: Peru Vows to Make Refinery Pay for Oil Spill After Tonga Volcano Eruption
item.description: A leak at a refinery tarred miles of Pacific Coast beaches. The company blames waves caused by a distant volcano eruption, but the Peruvian government has vowed to “defend the sea.”
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.media:credit: Angela Ponce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers cleaning up an oil spill last week in Ancon, Peru. Oil spilled from a refinery has washed up on 27 miles of coastline.

item.title: Sweden Announces an End to Covid Restrictions, Joining Other European Countries
item.description: Denmark, Norway and others have also been changing their approaches to the pandemic and scrapping many safety protocols.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Marko Saavala/TT News Agency, via AFP
item.media:description: “The pandemic is not over, but we are headed into a new phase,” Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson of Sweden said about the upcoming relaxation.

item.title: At Beijing Olympics, Question of Free Speech Looms Over Athletes
item.description: An Olympic rule and warnings from the Chinese government have made it risky for athletes to speak out at these Games.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Alan Blinder
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A view of Beijing on Wednesday from inside the main press center.

item.title: The Islamic State has shown that it can still pull off military operations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish security forces searching for Islamic State fighters near the Ghweiran prison in Hasaka, northeastern Syria, in January.

item.title: Read Biden’s statement on the ISIS leader’s death.
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: The N.F.L.’s Race Problem
item.description: Most of its players are Black. Only one head coach is.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Brian Flores.

item.title: How the Trojan Horse Affair Affected British Pakistanis
item.description: A scandal in 2014, known as the Trojan Horse affair, exposed what it’s like living in Britain as a British Pakistani.
item.dc:creator: Kalpesh Lathigra and Aina J. Khan

item.title: How Putin Has Prepared Russia's Economy for Sanctions
item.description: Since paying the price for annexing Crimea in 2014, Russia has tried to make its economy sanctions-proof, hoarding currency to insulate the country.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Moscow on Wednesday. Over the past several years, Russia’s economy has been reshaped to withstand Western financial pressure.

item.title: ‘Live With the Virus’? For Australians, It’s Taken Some Getting Used To.
item.description: Australia once stamped out every Covid outbreak. Now it’s done with all that. The policy U-turn, and the soaring case numbers, caught many off guard.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Bondi Beach in Sydney, Australia, last month. Australia went from “lockdowns when you can’t even have another person visit your house to full pubs,” one physician said.

item.title: Winter Olympics Open Amid Walls, Masks and Clouds of Disinfectant
item.description: With few spectators and strict security to separate China’s population from Olympic visitors, the Games are subdued.
item.dc:creator: Gabriela Bhaskar and Alan Blinder

item.title: Year of the Tiger Overshadows the Olympic Panda
item.description: In Beijing, the Lunar New Year has been a bigger preoccupation for many residents, while others have gone back to their hometowns for the holiday.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: In Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Putin to Meet Xi in Beijing Ahead of Winter Olympics
item.description: Russia’s president did not mention Ukraine, but said he and China’s leader would coordinate foreign policy “based on close and coinciding approaches.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a video conference with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in December. They will meet in person on Friday.

item.title: How Malaysia Got in on the Secondhand Clothing Boom
item.description: Sellers from the country have become a reliable source of sought-after labels, finding high value in discarded items.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Marcus
item.media:credit: Ian Teh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sora Bundle in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, is one of many secondhand stores in the country.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Military developments in Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Is Biden’s Strategy With Putin Working, or Goading Moscow to War?
item.description: The Biden administration’s goal is to cut the Russians off at each turn by exposing their plans. But Russian President Vladimir V. Putin says that approach could spark a conflict.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has accused the United States of reviving the Cold War strategy of containment and trying to goad him into an attack.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. to Send Troops to Eastern Europe
item.description: The move may reassure NATO allies anxious over tensions surrounding Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a house near the front-line in Chermalyk, Ukraine.

item.title: As Boris Johnson Seeks a Reset, More Tory Lawmakers Defect
item.description: Britain’s prime minister tried to steer attention away from a damning report on Downing Street parties, but his support continued to erode.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain departing 10 Downing Street for Parliament on Wednesday in London.
